titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Samuel DuBois Cook Papers, 1949-2015 RL.11747
titlestmt.author: Bethany Lynch, Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-02-19 18:55:42 UTC.

change.item: revised to include the processing of accession 2019-0131

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Dr. Samuel DuBois Cook (1928-2017) was a political scientist who became Duke University's first African American professor in 1966. He also served as president of Dillard University from 1975 to 1997. The Samuel DuBois Cook Papers contains Cook's speech files, drafts and copies of Cook's writings, and other assorted papers including correspondence and subject folders for his research and writings on Benjamin Elijah Mays. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into series: 1. General Papers. 2. Writings. 3. Speeches.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Samuel DuBois Cook (1928-2017) was a political scientist and professor who taught at Southern University, Atlanta University, the University of Illinois, UCLA, and Duke University, where in 1966, he became the first African American professor to hold a regular faculty appointment at a predominantly white college or university in the South. In 1975 he left Duke to became president of Dillard University, serving 22 years until his retirement in 1997. He also served as a member of the Duke University Board of Trustees from 1981 to 1993.

Additional information on the life of Samuel DuBois Cook can be found online at Duke University's Samuel DuBois Cook Center for Social Equity website: https://socialequity.duke.edu/about-samuel-dubois-cook

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Samuel DuBois Cook Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2018 and 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Samuel DuBois Cook Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Bethany Lynch, Meghan Lyon, June 2019
Addition processed by Jasmine Alexander-Greene and Alice Poffinberger, February 2020
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0032, 2019-0131

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Samuel DuBois Cook Papers contains Cook's speech files, drafts and copies of Cook's writings, and other assorted papers including correspondence and subject folders for his research and writings on Benjamin Elijah Mays. The correspondence is scattered but dates as early as 1949 and includes some exchanges between Cook and Duke University contacts and administration, written during his tenure as professor in the political science department. Later correspondence discusses Dillard University administration, as well as other personal and professional exchanges. Cook's research on Benjamin E. Mays includes files from his editing of the volume "Benjamin E. Mays: His Life, Contribution, and Legacy," published in 2009, as well as other drafts and files collected by Cook about Mays' writings and philosophy. Cook's other writings include drafts compiled for his Ford Foundation appointment researching desegregation and racism in the 1970s; writings and essays about Reinhold Niebuhr, Martin Luther King Jr., and historically black colleges; and his reflections on black power and the strategies of the civil rights movement. The bulk of the collection consists of Cook's speeches, filed into Dillard University and Professional Speeches subseries and arranged alphabetically by topic or title of the speech. Many of these are administrative, including many introductions of various Dillard speakers or other remarks delivered by Cook as Dillard University president.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Assorted incoming and outgoing correspondence from across Cook's personal and professional contacts. Materials have been sorted into loose chronological order, by year, but content ranges from professional commitments and responsibilities to Duke University and Dillard University; personal letters to friends and network contacts. Folders for 1967, 1972, 1976 all have letters from Benjamin E. Mays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Writings series includes conference papers and other articles by Cook; his research on Benjamin E. Mays, former president of Morehouse College; and a set of articles by others, edited by Cook, celebrating Mays. These articles were published in 2009 as "Benjamin E. Mays: His Life, Contributions, and Legacy". Articles and essays by Cook discuss black education, the civil rights movement, black power, and desegregation; he also writes about the lives and legacies of Benjamin E. Mays and Reinhold Niebuhr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filed by topic. Topics include: Chapel, Morehouse, Spirituality, "Free Minds in a Segregated Society," philosophy of social change, faculty, academic and intellectual freedom, Fund for Theological Education, Mays' funeral/obituaries. Files include Cook's notes/drafts as well as clippings and other collected subject matter.

did.unittitle: Clippings about Mays and his legacy
Mays' excerpts and clippings of his writings/speeches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cook's original drafts and introduction to Mays' biography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cook and his staff kept thorough speech files for different events and programs, largely dating between 1975 and 2000. The Speeches Series has been sorted into Dillard and non-Dillard Professional Speeches -- these divisions are based on whether Cook was presenting or officiating a program on behalf of Dillard University, (usually during his presidency), or whether he attended and spoke as a private citizen or scholar, outside of his official appointment as Dillard president. Speech folders have been arranged alphabetically, by type of speech or title of the speech. Files occasionally include multiple versions or drafts, accompanying material or programs from the event, or other logistical information about Cook's participation in the occasion.
